B. TechProject Phase I
ReportAnujBaliyan, 21116019
S u p e r v i s e d 
b y : 
P r o f . 
S p a r s h 
M i t t a l 
I n t r o d u c t i o n 
In 
factories 
and 
industries, 
the 
important 
parts 
of 
machines 
are 
rotating 
parts 
like 
rotors, 
shafts, 
and 
bearings. 
They 
should 
work 
smoothly 
to 
maintain 
everything 
running 
well 
and 
securely. 
But 
these 
parts 
can 
undergo 
fault 
at 
running 
time. 
These 
faults 
can 
lead 
to 
sudden 
breakdown 
of 
the 
mechanical 
system 
and 
accidents. 
So, 
it’s 
necessary 
to 
identify 
fault 
occurrences 
quickly 
and 
accurately.To 
do 
this, 
we 
use 
accelerometer 
sensors 
to 
get 
vibrational 
signal 
data 
from 
machine 
vibrations. 
These 
vibrations 
tell 
us 
about 
the 
health 
of 
working 
machines 
and 
if 
there 
are 
any 
issues. 
So, 
it 
is 
needed 
for 
early 
detection 
of 
faults 
and 
classifying 
the 
type 
of 
fault. 
We 
leveraged 
statistical 
and 
deep 
learning 
techniques 
to 
classify 
di ﬀ erent 
types 
of 
faults 
and 
starting 
time 
of 
fault. 
W o r k 
C o m p l e t e d 
S o 
F a r 
We 
previously 
worked 
on 
the 
data 
generation 
part. 
Collecting 
vibration 
data 
when 
machines 
are 
working 
normally 
is 
easy, 
but 
getting 
data 
related 
to 
faults 
is 
di ﬃ cult 
because 
faults 
don’t 
happen 
very 
often. 
This 
lack 
of 
fault 
data 
makes 
it 
hard 
to 
create 
strong 
models 
for 
detecting 
problems 
in 
machines. 
We 
have 
worked 
on 
solving 
the 
problem 
of 
lack 
of 
training 
data 
by 
using 
advanced 
Generative 
AI 
techniques, 
like 
Generative 
Adversarial 
Networks 
(GANs) 
and 
Di ﬀ usion 
Models 
. 
I 
have 
created 
GANs 
and 
Di ﬀ usion 
Model 
architecture 
for

synthetic 
signal 
generation 
to 
build 
robust 
deep 
learning 
classi ﬁ ers. 
This 
extra 
generated 
data 
helps 
to 
build 
robust 
machine 
learning 
bearing 
fault 
detection 
classi ﬁ ers. 
This 
approach 
boosts 
the 
ability 
to 
robustly 
classify 
faults 
more 
precisely. 
Dataset 
Previously 
we 
worked 
on 
case 
western 
Reserve 
University’s 
Bearing 
fault 
data 
for 
signal 
generation 
purpose 
task. 
Now 
we 
use 
the 
XJTU 
Dataset. 
The 
XJTU-SY 
bearing 
dataset 
was 
provided 
by 
the 
Institute 
of 
Design 
Science 
and 
Basic 
Components 
at 
Xi’an 
Jiaotong 
University 
(XJTU), 
Shaanxi, 
P.R. 
China, 
in 
collaboration 
with 
Changxing 
Sumyoung 
Technology 
Co., 
Ltd. 
(SY), 
Zhejiang, 
P.R. 
China. 
XJTU 
dataset 
consists 
of 
comprehensive 
run-to-failure 
data 
of 
15 
rolling 
element 
bearings, 
which 
were 
obtained 
through 
a 
series 
of 
accelerated 
degradation 
experiments 
conducted 
in 
the 
lab. 
The 
dataset 
is 
made 
publicly 
available. 
Here 
is 
the 
shown 
sample 
signal 
of 
XJTU 
dataset: 
 2

Here 
are 
the 
details 
of 
all 
15 
signals 
of 
dataset: 
F a u l t 
T h r e s h o l d i n g 
The 
signals 
are 
of 
a 
hybrid 
type, 
in 
starting 
these 
are 
in 
good 
working 
condition. 
But, 
after 
a 
certain 
point, 
their 
amplitude 
suddenly 
increases 
due 
to 
the 
occurrence 
of 
a 
fault 
in 
the 
bearing. 
My 
primary 
task 
was 
to 
accurately 
identify 
the 
boundary 
where 
the 
fault 
started. 
To 
address 
this, 
I 
proposed 
an 
anti-gradient-based 
approach 
to 
ﬁ rst 
smooth 
the 
signal. 
Then, 
I 
applied 
a 
Root 
Mean 
Squared 
Average 
(RMSA) 
over 
a 
sliding 
window. 
 3

Then 
using 
a 
threshold 
on 
the 
amplitude, 
to 
detect 
the 
boundary 
where 
the 
fault 
started. 
In 
signal 
processing, 
an 
anti-gradient 
method 
is 
to 
reduce 
sharp 
changes 
in 
the 
signal 
by 
countering 
gradients.Technically, 
It 
is 
integration 
over 
a 
period 
of 
time. 
I 
calculated 
anti-gradient 
up 
to 
the 
10th 
order, 
and 
tuned 
the 
order 
of 
anti-gradient 
to 
optimize 
computation 
and 
maintain 
accuracy. 
The 
optimal 
value 
was 
5th 
for 
order. 
Here, 
is 
the 
shown 
signal 
after 
applying 
5th 
order 
anti-gradient: 
We 
can 
capture 
the 
point 
where 
sudden 
change 
happened 
by 
taking 
gradient 
of 
the 
smoothened 
signal. 
These 
changes 
provide 
regions 
where 
the 
fault 
severity 
started 
to 
increase 
and 
provide 
clear 
transition 
from 
normal 
operation 
to 
fault 
condition. 
The 
thresholding 
of 
the 
signal 
classi ﬁ es 
it 
into 
three 
distinct 
regions 
based 
on 
fault 
severity. 
The 
ﬁ rst 
region 
is 
low 
severity 
, 
refers 
to 
normal 
operating 
conditions 
and 
there 
is 
no 
fault 
present. 
The 
second 
region 
is 
a 
moderate 
severity 
region, 
where 
the 
bearing 
is 
functional 
but 
provides 
concern 
of 
breaking 
o ﬀ 
the 
system 
. 
The 
third 
region 
is 
high 
severity 
, 
indicating 
that 
the 
bearing 
has 
failed 
and 
is 
almost 
near 
to 
complete 
breakdown 
of 
the 
system; 
it 
requires 
immediate 
intervention 
to 
prevent 
further 
damage 
to 
the 
system 
or 
failure 
of 
operation. 
Here 
is 
the 
signal 
shown 
after 
using 
threshold: 
 4

Here 
blue 
indicates 
low-moderate 
severity 
region 
separation 
line 
and 
red 
indicates 
moderate-high 
severity 
region 
separation. 
Visualization 
Previously, 
I 
worked 
on 
the 
visualization 
of 
the 
Case 
Western 
Reserve 
University 
(CWRU) 
dataset 
where 
I 
applied 
these 
techniques, 
and 
I 
applied 
the 
same 
techniques 
to 
the 
XJTU 
dataset 
also. 
Below 
are 
the 
methods 
listed 
I 
utilized 
in 
both 
projects: 
1. 
Wigner-Ville 
Distribution(WVD) 
: 
It 
is 
a 
time-frequency 
based 
technique 
which 
provides 
high-resolution 
features 
of 
the 
signal 
based 
on 
both 
time 
and 
frequency 
domains. 
2. 
Discrete 
Wavelet 
Transform 
(DWT) 
: 
In 
this 
method 
the 
signal 
is 
decomposed 
into 
various 
frequency 
bands, 
so 
that 
multi-resolution 
analysis 
can 
be 
done 
and 
both 
the 
low- 
and 
high-frequency 
components 
of 
the 
signal 
can 
be 
captured. 
3. 
Continuous 
Wavelet 
Transform 
(CWT) 
: 
Similar 
to 
the 
discrete 
wavelet, 
the 
continuous 
wavelet 
transform 
is 
for 
continuous 
time-frequency 
resolution, 
to 
get 
transient 
and 
localized 
features 
within 
the 
signal. 
 5

4. 
Short 
Time 
Fourier 
Transform 
(STFT) 
: 
This 
technique 
is 
used 
to 
analyse 
the 
signal's 
frequency 
content 
over 
small, 
overlapping 
time 
windows; 
it 
provides 
a 
balance 
between 
time 
and 
frequency 
resolution. 
5. 
Log-STFT 
: 
This 
is 
a 
modi ﬁ ed 
version 
of 
STFT 
where 
a 
logarithmic 
scale 
is 
applied 
to 
the 
output 
of 
STFT. 
This 
provides 
high 
resolution 
in 
the 
features 
generated 
by 
STFT. 
6. 
Gray 
Scale 
Matrix 
Mapping 
(GMM) 
: 
This 
is 
used 
to 
map 
time-domain 
signals 
into 
a 
matrix 
form, 
this 
provides 
correlation 
between 
a 
portion 
with 
another 
portion 
of 
signal. 
7. 
Non-Parametric 
Symmetrized 
Dot 
Pattern 
(NPASDP) 
: 
This 
method 
is 
used 
to 
generate 
patterns 
from 
the 
signal’s 
amplitude 
and 
phase 
information, 
which 
shows 
a 
unique 
pattern 
corresponding 
to 
di ﬀ erent 
signals. 
8. 
Discrete 
Cosine 
Transform 
(DCT) 
: 
This 
is 
the 
real 
data 
type 
variant 
of 
Fast-Fourier 
Transform 
used 
to 
transform 
signal 
to 
frequency 
domain, 
which 
focuses 
on 
compressing 
the 
signal’s 
energy 
into 
fewer 
coe ﬃ cients. 
This 
is 
useful 
for 
feature 
extraction 
and 
dimensionality 
reduction 
of 
the 
data. 
These 
techniques 
were 
applied 
to 
analyze 
and 
visualize 
the 
XJTU 
dataset, 
to 
enhance 
the 
understanding 
of 
characters 
of 
normal 
and 
faulty 
signals 
of 
di ﬀ erent 
fault 
types. 
Here 
are 
the 
image 
based 
representations 
for 
each 
technique:

f o l d e d

Fault 
Classi ﬁ cation 
Initially 
I 
used 
LeNet 
Classi ﬁ er, 
and 
the 
dataset 
was 
a 
set 
of 
images 
which 
were 
generated 
using 
the 
Wigner-Ville 
transform 
on 
one 
dimensional 
signal. 
The 
data 
was 
split 
into 
training, 
validation, 
and 
testing 
sets 
with 
an 
80:10:10 
ratio. 
I 
trained 
a 
baseline 
model 
on 
the 
unbalanced 
dataset 
with 
training 
dataset 
distribution 
of 
[3392, 
744, 
3406, 
6615]. 
The 
classi ﬁ cation 
accuracy 
on 
the 
model 
was 
95.74%, 
95.90%, 
and 
95.97%, 
respectively 
on 
the 
training, 
validation, 
and 
test 
datasets.The 
challenge 
faced 
by 
the 
model 
due 
to 
its 
training 
on 
the 
imbalance 
dataset 
was 
model 
over ﬁ tting 
and 
model 
bias, 
which 
overall 
a ﬀ ected 
the 
model's 
generalizing 
ability. 
For 
improving 
the 
model 
performance, 
the 
dataset 
was 
now 
balanced 
using 
dataset 
augmentation, 
and 
is 
the 
following 
distribution 
of 
dataset 
of 
each 
class: 
[2392, 
2976, 
3406, 
3315]. 
Also, 
the 
activation 
function 
was 
changed 
to 
improve 
the 
gradient 
ﬂ ow 
during 
model 
training. 
A 
signi ﬁ cant 
improvement 
in 
model 
performance 
was 
achieved, 
with 
training 
accuracy 
reaching 
99.95%, 
validation 
accuracy 
at 
99.83%, 
and 
testing 
accuracy 
at 
99.75% 
after 
doing 
all 
these 
changes. 
The 
classi ﬁ cation 
accuracy 
was 
signi ﬁ cantly 
low 
when 
using 
NPASDP 
images 
for 
classi ﬁ cation 
purposes. 
The 
observation 
was 
that 
the 
NPASDP 
technique 
is 
not 
well-suited 
for 
this 
XJTU 
dataset 
for 
classi ﬁ cation 
purposes. 
I 
tested 
the 
model’s 
performance 
on 
bearings 
that 
were 
not 
included 
in 
the 
training 
set 
to 
evaluate 
whether 
the 
model 
has 
generalizing 
ability. 
I 
trained 
the 
model 
on 
bearings 
B2_1, 
B2_2, 
and 
B2_3, 
and 
tested 
on 
bearings 
B2_4 
and 
B2_5 
and 
the 
accuracy 
of 
the 
model 
was 
signi ﬁ cantly 
low. 
I 
also 
tested 
on 
the 
datasets 
of 
other 
load 
conditions 
of 
bearing 
and 
model 
resulted 
in 
low 
performance.

vibrations.

on

western 
Reserve 
University’s 
Bearing 
fault 
data 
for

generation 
purpose 
task.

we 
use

XJTU 
Dataset.

XJTU-SY 
bearing 
dataset

University 
(XJTU),

in

Sumyoung

Co.,

(SY),

P.R. 
China. 
XJTU 
dataset 
consists 
of 
comprehensive 
run-to-failure 
data 
of 
15 
rolling 
element 
bearings, 
which 
were 
obtained 
through 
a 
series 
of

The

is

Here 
are 
the 
details 
of 
all 
15 
signals 
of 
dataset: 
F a u l t 
T h r e s h o l d i n g 
The 
signals 
are 
of 
a 
hybrid 
type, 
in 
starting 
these 
are 
in 
good 
working 
condition. 
But, 
after 
a 
certain 
point, 
their 
amplitude 
suddenly 
increases 
due 
to 
the 
occurrence 
of 
a 
fault 
in 
the 
bearing. 
My 
primary 
task 
was 
to 
accurately 
identify 
the 
boundary 
where 
the 
fault 
started. 
To 
address 
this, 
I 
proposed 
an 
anti-gradient-based 
approach 
to 
ﬁ rst 
smooth 
the 
signal. 
Then, 
I 
applied 
a 
Root 
Mean 
Squared 
Average 
(RMSA) 
over 
a 
sliding 
window. 
 3
Page 6 of 14 - Integrity Submission
Submission ID trn:oid:::1:3095655596
Page 6 of 14 - Integrity Submission
Submission ID trn:oid:::1:3095655596

Then 
using 
a 
threshold 
on 
the 
amplitude, 
to 
detect 
the 
boundary 
where 
the 
fault 
started. 
In 
signal 
processing, 
an 
anti-gradient 
method 
is 
to 
reduce 
sharp 
changes 
in 
the 
signal 
by 
countering 
gradients.Technically, 
It 
is 
integration 
over 
a 
period 
of 
time. 
I 
calculated 
anti-gradient 
up 
to 
the 
10th 
order, 
and 
tuned 
the 
order 
of 
anti-gradient 
to 
optimize 
computation 
and 
maintain 
accuracy. 
The 
optimal 
value 
was 
5th 
for 
order. 
Here, 
is 
the 
shown 
signal 
after 
applying 
5th 
order 
anti-gradient: 
We 
can 
capture 
the 
point 
where 
sudden 
change 
happened 
by 
taking 
gradient 
of 
the 
smoothened 
signal. 
These 
changes 
provide 
regions 
where 
the 
fault 
severity 
started 
to 
increase 
and 
provide 
clear 
transition 
from 
normal 
operation 
to 
fault 
condition. 
The 
thresholding 
of 
the 
signal 
classi ﬁ es 
it 
into 
three 
distinct 
regions 
based 
on 
fault 
severity. 
The 
ﬁ rst 
region 
is 
low 
severity 
, 
refers 
to 
normal 
operating 
conditions 
and 
there 
is 
no 
fault 
present. 
The 
second 
region 
is 
a 
moderate 
severity 
region, 
where 
the 
bearing 
is 
functional 
but 
provides 
concern 
of 
breaking 
o ﬀ 
the 
system 
. 
The 
third 
region 
is 
high 
severity 
, 
indicating 
that 
the 
bearing 
has 
failed 
and 
is 
almost 
near 
to 
complete 
breakdown 
of 
the 
system; 
it 
requires 
immediate 
intervention 
to 
prevent 
further 
damage 
to 
the 
system 
or 
failure 
of 
operation. 
Here 
is 
the 
signal 
shown 
after 
using 
threshold:

Visualization 
Previously, 
I 
worked 
on 
the 
visualization 
of 
the 
Case 
Western 
Reserve 
University 
(CWRU) 
dataset 
where 
I 
applied 
these 
techniques, 
and 
I 
applied 
the 
same 
techniques 
to 
the 
XJTU 
dataset 
also. 
Below 
are 
the 
methods 
listed 
I 
utilized 
in 
both 
projects: 
1. 
Wigner-Ville 
Distribution(WVD) 
: 
It 
is 
a 
time-frequency 
based 
technique 
which 
provides 
high-resolution 
features 
of 
the 
signal 
based 
on 
both 
time 
and 
frequency 
domains. 
2. 
Discrete 
Wavelet 
Transform 
(DWT) 
: 
In 
this 
method 
the 
signal 
is 
decomposed 
into 
various 
frequency 
bands, 
so 
that 
multi-resolution 
analysis 
can 
be 
done 
and 
both 
the 
low- 
and 
high-frequency 
components 
of 
the 
signal 
can 
be 
captured. 
3. 
Continuous 
Wavelet 
Transform 
(CWT) 
: 
Similar 
to 
the 
discrete 
wavelet, 
the 
continuous 
wavelet 
transform 
is 
for 
continuous 
time-frequency 
resolution, 
to 
get 
transient 
and 
localized 
features 
within 
the 
signal. 
 5
7
Page 8 of 14 - Integrity Submission
Submission ID trn:oid:::1:3095655596
Page 8 of 14 - Integrity Submission
Submission ID trn:oid:::1:3095655596

4. 
Short 
Time 
Fourier 
Transform 
(STFT) 
: 
This 
technique 
is 
used 
to 
analyse 
the 
signal's 
frequency 
content 
over 
small, 
overlapping 
time 
windows; 
it 
provides 
a 
balance 
between 
time 
and 
frequency 
resolution. 
5. 
Log-STFT 
: 
This 
is 
a 
modi ﬁ ed 
version 
of 
STFT 
where 
a 
logarithmic 
scale 
is 
applied 
to 
the 
output 
of 
STFT. 
This 
provides 
high 
resolution 
in 
the 
features 
generated 
by 
STFT. 
6. 
Gray 
Scale 
Matrix 
Mapping 
(GMM) 
: 
This 
is 
used 
to 
map 
time-domain 
signals 
into 
a 
matrix 
form, 
this 
provides 
correlation 
between 
a 
portion 
with 
another 
portion 
of 
signal. 
7. 
Non-Parametric 
Symmetrized 
Dot 
Pattern 
(NPASDP) 
: 
This 
method 
is 
used 
to 
generate 
patterns 
from 
the 
signal’s 
amplitude 
and 
phase 
information, 
which 
shows 
a 
unique 
pattern 
corresponding 
to 
di ﬀ erent 
signals. 
8. 
Discrete 
Cosine 
Transform 
(DCT) 
: 
This 
is 
the 
real 
data 
type 
variant 
of 
Fast-Fourier 
Transform 
used 
to 
transform 
signal 
to 
frequency 
domain, 
which 
focuses 
on 
compressing 
the 
signal’s 
energy 
into 
fewer 
coe ﬃ cients. 
This 
is 
useful 
for 
feature 
extraction 
and 
dimensionality 
reduction 
of 
the 
data. 
These 
techniques 
were 
applied 
to 
analyze 
and 
visualize 
the 
XJTU 
dataset, 
to 
enhance 
the 
understanding 
of 
characters 
of 
normal 
and 
faulty 
signals 
of 
di ﬀ erent 
fault 
types. 
Here 
are 
the 
image 
based 
representations 
for 
each 
technique:

Fault 
Classi ﬁ cation 
Initially 
I 
used 
LeNet 
Classi ﬁ er, 
and 
the 
dataset 
was 
a 
set 
of 
images 
which 
were 
generated 
using 
the 
Wigner-Ville 
transform 
on 
one 
dimensional 
signal. 
The 
data 
was 
split 
into 
training, 
validation, 
and 
testing 
sets 
with 
an 
80:10:10 
ratio. 
I 
trained 
a 
baseline 
model 
on 
the 
unbalanced 
dataset 
with 
training 
dataset 
distribution 
of 
[3392, 
744, 
3406, 
6615]. 
The 
classi ﬁ cation 
accuracy 
on 
the 
model 
was 
95.74%, 
95.90%, 
and 
95.97%, 
respectively 
on 
the 
training, 
validation, 
and 
test 
datasets.The 
challenge 
faced 
by 
the 
model 
due 
to 
its 
training 
on 
the 
imbalance 
dataset 
was 
model 
over ﬁ tting 
and 
model 
bias, 
which 
overall 
a ﬀ ected 
the 
model's 
generalizing 
ability. 
For 
improving 
the 
model 
performance, 
the 
dataset 
was 
now 
balanced 
using 
dataset 
augmentation, 
and 
is 
the 
following 
distribution 
of 
dataset 
of 
each 
class: 
[2392, 
2976, 
3406, 
3315]. 
Also, 
the 
activation 
function 
was 
changed 
to 
improve 
the 
gradient 
ﬂ ow 
during 
model 
training. 
A 
signi ﬁ cant 
improvement 
in 
model 
performance 
was 
achieved, 
with 
training 
accuracy 
reaching 
99.95%, 
validation 
accuracy 
at 
99.83%, 
and 
testing 
accuracy 
at 
99.75% 
after 
doing 
all 
these 
changes. 
The 
classi ﬁ cation 
accuracy 
was 
signi ﬁ cantly 
low 
when 
using 
NPASDP 
images 
for 
classi ﬁ cation 
purposes. 
The 
observation 
was 
that 
the 
NPASDP 
technique 
is 
not 
well-suited 
for 
this 
XJTU 
dataset 
for 
classi ﬁ cation 
purposes. 
I 
tested 
the 
model’s 
performance 
on 
bearings 
that 
were 
not 
included 
in 
the 
training 
set 
to 
evaluate 
whether 
the 
model 
has 
generalizing 
ability. 
I 
trained 
the 
model 
on 
bearings 
B2_1, 
B2_2, 
and 
B2_3, 
and 
tested 
on 
bearings 
B2_4 
and 
B2_5 
and 
the 
accuracy 
of 
the 
model 
was 
signi ﬁ cantly 
low. 
I 
also 
tested 
on 
the 
datasets 
of 
other 
load 
conditions 
of 
bearing 
and 
model 
resulted 
in 
low 
performance. 
The 
results 
are 
summarized 
in 
the 
table 
below:
